subtitle: [Music]
Thinking Allowed.
Conversations on the leading edge of
knowledge and discovery
with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Once again I'm here to have a conversation with
myself.
That's me. We're going to be talking about
the persistence of discarnate entities
in the afterlife. And
what I mean by persistence in
this instance is how long does a
discarnate human entity
remain in communication? Now,
lots of people report ongoing
communications with their deceased loved ones
and friends sometimes for years, but typically
they are short-lived and brief as a
matter of fact.
We don't know how easy or hard it is
if you're there on the other side
to communicate. But some
discarnate entities seem to persist for over
a hundred years. Let's begin
there. Probably the most
persistent one is an entity known as John
King who first appeared in 1850,
as I recall, in seances with the
Davenport brothers
in the United States. Later on John
King appeared in seances all around the
world. It seemed as
if mediums everywhere wanted to invoke John
King who also indicated that he was
actually the, John King being the, I don't
know, spirit name
that he used. But he in life had been
Henry Morgan, the buccaneer pirate who
was later appointed, as I recall,
governor of Jamaica. So
he seems to be a very persistent
and active communicator. And not just
a communicator, he was involved
in the production of materializations, a very
dramatic physical phenomenon. So dramatic
that even today every instance
remains highly controversial. The reason is
simply because there are people who
won't believe it no matter what.
As one scientist said, “I don't want to
believe it even if it's true.”
So, these phenomena will
always be controversial. But the
controversy extends
beyond what the hardcore skeptics
have to say about it.
I believe of course they're wrong
because they're wedded to
a materialistic metaphysics which is in
deep, deep trouble these days.
In fact, pretty much invalid in my view.
But I don't want to go there now.
We've done many
New Thinking Allowed interviews about
that topic. The point I want to make is this:
is John King a real discarnate human
or is it the invention of the mediums
themselves? If you're
a trans-medium or if you're in a circle,
a spiritualist circle, and you're interested in cultivating
physical mediumship and phenomena,
wouldn't you wish to
invoke the name of a spirit who already has
a reputation for producing phenomena
of this sort? Well, it does seem logical
to me that you would want to do that, but
does that in and of itself
mean that the many manifestations —
I think John King may be the most popular
spirit guide in the history of spiritualism — but
all of these manifestations and the desire
of humans to invoke or conjure
or create a John King, does that
invalidate the essence of the
actual discarnate entity?
It doesn't. I think that these things can
operate in tandem. In fact, necessarily
operate in tandem. William James, the great
founder of American parapsychology...
Well, let me start over with that. William
James, the founder of American psychology
and also one of the pioneer psychical researchers.
The term parapsychology wasn't really in
use very much in James's lifetime.
But he maintained in his study of trans-
mediums, which was quite extensive,
that there are two wills operating when a
spirit manifests. There's the will of the
external entity
and there's the will of the medium to personate
that entity. So they go together hand in hand.
I might add that James added another
wrinkle to all of this. He said, we don't
know for example that
the spirit calling itself John King, the
pirate governor of Jamaica,
Henry Morgan, was that really
him? Or could it have been, as was suggested
by Madame Blavatsky, the founder of
the Theosophical Society, that the
spiritualists got it wrong and that
these so-called
spirits they were invoking were actually
daemonic entities. They were discarnate
all right but they weren't discarnate
humans. They were
inhabitants of the discarnate world who
had access, you could say, to the Akashic
records, what William James called the cosmic
reservoir that
contained all knowledge and that they
were using their knowledge to deceive
people. Even today I hear from many people,
particularly devout Christians, who
maintain that this is the case, that the
spiritualists are being deceived not by
daemonic but by demonic entities.
So it's a very, very complex area. You mentioned
that John King first manifested in the 1850s,
30 years before the founding of the
Society for Psychical Research in
England. After all, spiritualism as a
phenomenon, as a
recent phenomenon, began in the United
States with the Fox sisters in
around 1848 and it swept
across the world. It was like the
consciousness movement today, the
psychedelic movement, the
human potential movement, in an era
in which people didn't have televisions
to watch all the time.
Throughout the world they gathered in
small circles to hold
seances. The reports of these phenomena are
really quite extensive. Thousands
of instances of paranormal occurrences
are in the literature. But John King
to my understanding actually has manifested as
recently as 1980. Well,
sometime between 1961 and 1981
John G. Neihardt, who was the poet laureate
of Missouri and the author of a best-selling book
called Black Elk Speaks, he himself was
an initiate in the Oglala Sioux
shamanic tradition, initiated by Black Elk
himself. In 1961 when he was a
professor at the University of Missouri
he formed a group called the Society for
Research on Rapport and Telekinesis,
otherwise known as SORRAT.
They produced a wide range of physical phenomena.
They had a wide range of
entities that came through as communicators.
One of them was John King.
Another communicator was called Three by Three and
claimed to be a manifestation from the
subconscious mind
of one of the researchers, W. Edward
Cox. So you can get quite a mixture going on. But
if we go from 1850 to about
let's say 1980 you're talking about the
persistence of a spiritual entity for 130
years on the other side. Now, why would
that happen?
So much of the spiritualist literature
suggests that
once you're on the other side you want
to evolve. You're going to
either maybe be reincarnated,
you're going to pursue higher levels of
the spiritual planes,
ultimately moving closer and closer to
the absolute. But
why would you maintain a consistent
apparently non-evolving personality
for 130 years when you're on the other side?
It does suggest, or it leads
a little bit more credence to the idea that these
mythical guides like John King are actually
products of the human imagination, the
living human
imagination. Certainly we can't rule that
out. But I'll give you another example
similar to John King
is Walter Stinson. Walter Stinson was the
brother of a great medium in the early
part of the 20th century,
Mena Crandon, also known as the medium
Margery. It was a
pseudonym I guess she used to protect
her identity.
Margery attracted worldwide
attention. She was in the newspapers
all the time because Scientific American
magazine back in the 1920s was offering
a cash reward for anyone who could demonstrate
paranormal phenomena.
She was tested. She was the wife of a Harvard
physician, and a very well-to-do charming
woman who could go into trance and
produce a wide range
of physical phenomena. Her main
spirit guide was her younger brother
Walter Stinson, who apparently died in a
train crash I think around 1911,
as I recall. Now, Walter Stinson has
appeared in seances long after Margery's death.
Well, in about 1925 Margery and her husband went
on tour and they visited spiritualist
centers around North America.
One of those centers was in
Winnipeg, Canada. It was a very well-known
organization developed by Thomas Glenn Denning
Hamilton, a medical doctor in Canada
who did extensive
well documented research on physical phenomena.
I think it was about 1926 when
Margery and her husband visited.
Thereafter in the seances in Winnipeg, Walter
Stinson appeared and the phenomena, largely
ectoplasmic manifestations and apports.
Well documented. They had a seance room with
dozens of cameras set up to capture
anything that might occur.
There are many, many records now in
the archives, as I recall, at the
University of Manitoba of these phenomena.
So, why is it the visit of Margery
triggered the association with the
spirit guide Walter? Now, what we don't have
are, to my knowledge, are records that
indicate that Walter Stinson provided
proof of his identity
at any time. I think Margery and her
husband certainly believed it and they
would have had
reason to do so having grown up with Walter. But
the Hamiltons in Canada never knew
Walter and it's not at all clear to me
that they were even interested in establishing his
identity. What they were interested in is the
phenomena that he produced.
In a way, you could say those phenomena are a
signature. Interestingly enough,
Walter Stinson is today
one of the main spirit guides working through
Stewart Alexander in England. Now, you will
find, and I'm going to link right now
over here on the right side of your screen
to two of the interviews
with Stewart Alexander, a great physical medium
who has been studied
by members of the Society for Psychical
Research in England. There have been some
publications attesting
to his authentic physical mediumship producing
flying trumpets, direct voice materializations.
Also, that work is discussed, and I'm gonna link to
another interview with Leslie Kean who
works with Stewart Alexander to this day.
So here you have,
if we are to take Walter Stinson's
manifestations at face value,
producing physical phenomena,
the kind that are so astounding that
many skeptics just say out of hand it
can't be true, this is childish nonsense
and I won't have a word of it.
That really pretty much is their
attitude. Fair enough.
But it's a signature though of
Walter Stinson, in my estimation, and it
suggests to me
that a spirit like John King or Walter Stinson
might persist in the afterlife and communicate
over and over again in different
mediumistic circles.
Because, number one, they have the energy,
they have whatever psychokinetic or spiritual
power is required to do this, and they have a
certain attachment
to the earthly plane to see it happen, to
provide proof of their existence.
That's their motivation, that's their
intention. I don't think we can dismiss
that lightly either. I tend to think these things
operate all together, in combination.
Well, it is interesting that if we look at the
classical cases of the reincarnation type
of the sort that have been investigated
at the University of Virginia
by Ian Stevenson and other colleagues
there, Jim Tucker and others. James Matlock
has done a long series of interviews with me
about these cases. I'll link here
on the right side of your screen to the
first one of those.
The point that I want to make here is
that when young children get
in touch with a past life memory the
memory tends to fade.
They talk about it a lot starting as
soon as they can talk, maybe at the age of two
or three. By the time they reach
puberty they have other interests, and of course
that's part of human development.
They want to be accepted by their
peers, they want to socialize, they want to
become a human in this lifetime.
So the past life memories fade.
You don't get the same kind of persistence
in reincarnation cases. But, as I reported in
an earlier monologue on spirit
possession, I'm linking to it now,
there are cases of spirit possession.
Typically how this works, it's sometimes called
replacement reincarnation, a person
is on the verge of death and they apparently die.
But before the body can be buried
they wake up and they're alive and active
and moving around. However, it seems to be
a different individual,
an individual with a different name and
a different history, memories,
even different language patterns.
These individuals, you could say they are a
possession or a replacement
reincarnation. They persist.
There's good reason to think that those
personalities
might last throughout the rest of the lifetime
of that individual, maybe as long as 60
years.
So, there's so much we don't know. There's
so much we have to learn about this
field. It is so complex. Why is it complex?
Because we're dealing
with human consciousness itself. You know,
we think we know a little bit about
consciousness, everyday waking consciousness where
we're mostly interacting in the physical world.
We know a lot less about dreams, we know
a lot less
about lucid dreaming. It is important to
acknowledge that the great
psychologist of the unconscious mind, Carl Jung,
felt that the collective
unconscious, the consciousness that is shared
by all of us — one might even say it's
equivalent to the mystical one mind — contains
the bardo planes, the afterlife,
as well as all of our fantasies and dreams and
tulpas and wishes.
You know, since I've mentioned the term tulpa
there I'm going to link to my previous
monologue about tulpas
as well, because that's another wrinkle to add to
the puzzle. Well, I think we've
covered this topic as well as we can in a
succinct conversation like this. So
I want to thank you for being with me.
You know it is
always a pleasure. And for those of you
watching or listening, thank you for being with
us.
[Music]
